However, Google currently does, providing a browser-controlled UI that looks very similar to Google Identity Services’ OneTap widget where third-party cookies are already shared. This is evidence of a bug in the specification, not a feature of “engine freedom” to develop innovative UI. We believe the reduced scope of the Lightweight FedCM proposal is much closer to appropriately balancing the interests of developers and users and is much more likely to reach a solution all browsers would implement.

620.title: Speculation Rules - Navigational prefetching and prerendering

622.title: Topics API
622.description: The goal of the Topics API is to provide callers with coarse-grained advertising topics that the page visitor might currently be interested in.
622.rationale: Mozilla is unable to see a way to make the Topics API work from a privacy standpoint. Though the information the API provides is small, our belief is that this is more likely to reduce the usefulness of the information for advertisers than it provides meaningful protection for privacy.  Unfortunately, it is hard to identify concrete ways in which this might be improved.

632.title: WebDriver-BiDi
632.description: The BiDirectional WebDriver Protocol, a mechanism for remote control of user agents.
632.rationale: Automation is an important capability for the web platform - for example, reliable automated testing makes it easier for websites to offer a functional user experience. The current standard protocol for building these tools has fallen behind demonstrated needs, which has in part led to new tools being built on Chrome DevTools Protocol. This makes it harder to automate across multiple browsers and versions of browsers - it’d be better for the standard protocol to support these needs.

636.title: Multi-Screen Window Placement: Fullscreen Companion Window

637.title: Streams for the Web Cryptography API

646.title: Shared Storage
646.description: Shared storage is storage for an origin that is intentionally not partitioned by top-frame site. Storage may only be read in a restricted environment that has carefully constructed output gates.
646.rationale: Mozilla has significant concerns about the viability of the isolation components of this design. The use cases presented do not, at this time, justify the complexity and privacy risks associated with this proposal.

650.title: Auto-sizes for lazy-loaded images in HTML
650.description: Allow authors to omit the 'sizes' attribute, use the keyword 'auto', for responsive lazy images in HTML to let the browser use the layout size from CSS or width/height attributes.
650.rationale: This proposal makes it easier for web developers to use responsive images. There is some risk that the behavior of cached images can cause flicker in some cases.

662.title: Render blocking status in Resource Timing

665.title: HTTP response status code in Resource Timing

666.title: Subset of CSP 3: script-src-elem, script-src-attr, style-src-elem and style-src-attr

668.title: Mixed Content Level 2
668.description: This specification describes how a user agent should handle fetching of content over unencrypted or unauthenticated connections in the context of an encrypted and authenticated document.
668.rationale: Managing mixed content has been an important cornerstone of the migration to more HTTPS. The level 2 spec is an important step towards more HTTPS adoption and has the potential to also improve the user experience on sites with accidentally mixed content.

675.title: Autoplay Policy Detection API
675.description: This specification provides web developers the ability to detect if automatically starting the playback of a media file is allowed in different situations.
675.rationale: This API provides a convenient and synchronous answer to whether a particular kind of media can autoplay, which is something web developers are currently detecting either with various hacks or through UA detection. This doesn't expose new information for fingerprinting (see w3c/autoplay#24) as media elements already expose through events which media will autoplay by trying to autoplay.

677.title: View Transitions API
677.description: The View Transitions API allows developers to create animated visual transitions representing changes in the document state.
677.rationale: View Transitions allows developers to create animated transitions between states within one document as well as transitions when navigating across documents. The latter is a new capability for the web. We think the API design should be consistent between these cases where possible. As of mid-2023, the specification and implementation experience for this feature for same-document transitions is further along than for cross-document transitions.

678.title: CHIPS (Cookies Having Independent Partitioned State)
678.description: Defines the Partitioned cookie attribute. This attribute will indicate to user agents that these cross-site cookies should only be available in the same top-level context that the cookie was created in.
678.rationale: This spec provides an opt-in mechanism to enable partitioned cookies. This allows more browsers to support partitioned cookies, and once adopted by sites can facilitate the default blocking of third-party cookies.

685.title: User Agent automation for Custom Handlers

690.title: Support IPv6 Zone Identifiers in Address Literals

695.title: CSS Nesting Module Level 1
695.description: This module introduces the ability to nest one style rule inside another, with the selector of the child rule relative to the selector of the parent rule.  This increases the modularity and maintainability of CSS stylesheets.
695.rationale: Nesting is a valuable tool for simplifying CSS authoring. Many authoring formats include the capability in some form, but native support will make the capability consistent and more widely available.

698.title: The Popover API
698.description: Adds the global popover attribute to declaratively make an element be rendered on top of all other content and allow closing by the user (light dismiss).
698.rationale: A common paradigm on the web which would be good for accessibility and developer ergonomics to support as a feature in HTML.

706.title: Face Detection MediaStreamTrack constraints and VideoFrame metadata

715.title: Extending the PointerEvent with Unique DeviceId Attribute

718.title: Remove support for data: URL in SVGUseElement

720.title: Revisiting negative positions through Add-On Gating

722.title: Interim response timings in resource timing

728.title: Programatically disabling hardware encoding/decoding in WebRTC

737.title: Never Unpartition Storage APIs via the Storage Access API

738.title: Implement subset of File System Access API

743.title: MathML colspan attribute for the `<mtd>` element

744.title: Skip service worker no-op fetch handler

745.title: Use `v` flag instead of `u` for HTML `pattern` attribute RegExps

760.title: Expanded Wildcards in Permissions Policy Origins

767.title: Report Critical-CH caused restart in NavigationTiming

769.title: Unsanitized HTML read/write in Async Clipboard API

775.title: Zstandard compression format for Content-Encoding
775.description: Zstandard, or "zstd" (pronounced "zee standard"), is a data compression mechanism. This document describes the mechanism and registers a media type and content encoding to be used when transporting zstd-compressed content via Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME). Despite use of the word "standard" as part of its name, readers are advised that this document is not an Internet Standards Track specification; it is being published for informational purposes only.
775.rationale: Zstandard/Zstd has been shown to be an effective compression scheme especially for dynamic content, by reducing load on servers to deliver the same level of compression.   It also enables improvements from future work on Compression Dictionaries.  Chrome shipped support for Zstd in early 2024, and Firefox followed soon after.  It has been judged to be worth the ongoing cost in maintenance and complexity to support for decompression, and is also useful for supporting TLS certificate decompression.

776.title: Adding payto protocol to the registerProtocolHandler safelist.

779.title: Add a capability to create a Blob URL with a unique (non-opaque) origin

782.title: Submitting element directionality via the dirname attribute

794.title: CSS Anchor Positioning
794.description: Anchor Positioning allows positioned elements to size and position themselves relative to one or more 'anchor elements' elsewhere on the page.
794.rationale: This is an important evolution of absolute positioning that addresses a common and much requested authoring use case that otherwise requires the use of JavaScript.

801.title: Add value argument to URLSearchParams's has() and delete()

804.title: Ignore target names which contain both `\n` and `<` characters

806.title: Standardizing Security Semantics for Cross-Site Cookies

828.title: ServiceWorker static routing API
828.description: The initial proposal allows ServiceWorkers to define routes using URLPattern to bypass the ServiceWorker, avoiding spurious ServiceWorker wake-ups and avoiding the additional latency of sending requests to the ServiceWorker that it will not handle.  Longer term, the mechanism could also support consulting the Cache API without needing to wake up a ServiceWorker.
828.rationale: A longstanding performance concern for ServiceWorkers and the sites using them is that there is no way to skip going to a ServiceWorker for a controlled page when there is a "fetch" handler present.  The Static Routing API has been recognized as an ideal solution to address the problem versus other proposals like adding new attributes to HTML tags or arguments to the fetch API.  The static routing API had been discussed extensively in ServiceWorker WG meetings as a reasonable option but very complex to implement and specify, which is why it was not part of the original spec.  With the introduction of the URLPattern API, the Static Routing API is thankfully even easier to implement and specify.  The evolutionary approach where the Static Routing API will only start with a network source that bypasses the ServiceWorker is appropriately pragmatic.

835.title: Bounce Tracking Mitigations
835.description: This specification defines navigational tracking and when and how browsers are required to prevent it from happening.
835.rationale: With 3rd-party cookies being restricted by default in all major browsers, navigational tracking plays an increasingly important role on the web. This spec describes an effective cross-browser mechanism to combat bounce tracking, which does not rely on tracker lists. It provides predictable detection heuristics for web developers and preserves legitimate uses of short-lived redirects where possible. While browsers already ship similar protections, e.g. Firefox's tracker purging, aligning on common behavior improves web compatibility and encourages site developers to use specialized APIs, rather than relying on top level redirects for functionality.

838.title: UserActivation API
838.description: The UserActivation API provides the ability to query whether the window currently has or has previously had real user interaction.
838.rationale: This API exposes the sticky activation and transient activation concepts which browsers use internally for, e.g., allowing popups. These concepts are useful for web apps as well.

841.title: CSS Color 5: Relative Color Syntax
841.description: Relative color syntax (RCS) allows developers to create a range of dynamic colors, starting from a base color, that will change as the base color changes. Great for creating color palettes and schemes.
841.rationale: Enables more freedom for developers to make use of the new forms and spaces introduced in CSS Color Module Level 4.

844.title: Locale Extensions
844.description: Exposes to the Web user preferences for hour cycle, first day of week, temperature unit, numbering system, and calendar system overriding values implied by language-region pair
844.rationale: Use cases have legitimacy, but they don't seem strong enough to justify the additional fingerprinting surface. Addressing fingerprinting, if even possible, would likely to involve disproportionate design, engineering, and UI surface relative to the utility.

845.title: ManagedMediaSource API
845.description: This proposal extends Media Source Extension objects with a number of features that allow web applications to be more efficient in terms of power usage and memory.
845.rationale: This opt-in feature of Media Source Extension allows implementations to reclaim memory when needed, and to allows scheduling download of media data when it's best to do so in terms of power usage. This is especialy important on mobile. This has the potential to improve the experience of media playback on low-power devices, but also generally allows web applications to use resources more efficiently.

848.title: Clear Client Hints via Clear-Site-Data header

855.title: New attribute to control UA-provided writing assistance

858.title: WebRTC RtpSender setParameter extensions for requesting keyframe generation

860.title: Opaque Response Blocking
860.description: Safelist certain opaque responses based on MIME type and block everything else.
860.rationale: Our preferred approach to handle opaque responses when defending against Spectre attacks.

861.title: Multiple Readers and Writers in File System Access API

867.title: Global Privacy Control (GPC)
867.description: This spec defines a signal that conveys a person's request to websites and services to not sell or share their personal information with third parties.
867.rationale: This signal defined in this specification provides users with a way to opt-out of the disclosure of their information to third parties once per profile in a way that is legally enforced in some jurisdictions, and is being considered in future regulations.

878.title: Remove same-origin blanket enforcement from CSP Embedded Enforcement

889.title: Feature detection for supported clipboard formats

891.title: TextTrackCue enhancements for programmatic subtitle and caption presentation

898.title: Extending Storage Access API (SAA) to non-cookie storage

902.title: Invokers (`command` & `commandfor`)
902.description: Invokers allow authors to assign behaviour to buttons in a more accessible and declarative way.
902.rationale: This proposal reduces the need for JavaScript for pages to build interactive elements. Using invokers is more likely to result in good accessibility and device-independence than existing methods.

903.title: CSS Text Level 4: the `text-spacing` property and its longhands

929.title: Long Animation Frame
929.description: This specification defines APIs for reporting information for frames that take a long time to render.
929.rationale: This feature allows web developers to measure frame congestion and jank, and has a correlation with how user perceive this type of congestion. Web developers can use this API to improve the perceived performance of their pages.

931.title: WebGPU default entry points to shader modules

938.title: New 'onmove' event handler for the Window object

944.title: WebAssembly JS Promise Integration
944.rationale: Addresses a major paint point for developers porting existing applications that assume synchronous I/O to the web.

954.title: Private Access Tokens
954.description: Private Access Tokens is the name given to the [integration](https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=huqjyh7k) of Privacy Pass mechanism into Apple's networking stack.
954.rationale: This application of Privacy Pass fairly closely follows the IETF specification, but the integration with the Web means that the effect is of a proprietary deployment. A number of considerations relevant to use on the Web have not been adequately addressed in the deployment.

964.title: WebAuthn: Allow for credential creation in a cross-origin iframe

966.title: WebSockets: Allow http(s) scheme and relative URLs

972.description: These CSS properties provide control over typographic widows and orphans during fragmentation/pagination.

996.title: MediaRecorder: Support mp4 container with avc1 and mp4a.40.2 codecs for MediaRecorder

1003.title: Digital Credentials
1003.description: The digital credentials API is an extension to the credential management API that enables access to identity documentation that might be held in the user agent or a wallet on the same device.
1003.rationale: This interface carries a significant risk of causing privacy problems and could lead to unjustified exclusion of web users. Any solution in this area needs to do more to manage these risks before it could be considered safe to deploy.

1009.title: Constructors for RTC Encoded Frames with metadata

1012.title: document.caretPositionFromPoint API in shadow DOM scenario

1014.title: Reduce Accept-Language
1014.description: Describes a technique to limit the languages sent in the Accept-Language header to a single language to reduce the passive fingerprint sent by a user.
1014.rationale: Mozilla is exploring anti-fingerprinting engineering proposals. While this is interesting to consider, until we know how much it would actually help our users and how much it would affect the web, we will defer an opinion.

1017.title: Allow converting VideoFrame to RGB pixel formats by calling VideoFrame.copyTo()

1048.title: CSS Nesting: The Nested Declarations Rule
1048.description: Implicit rules created by nesting create a new kind of rule, not an style rule
1048.rationale: Straight improvement to the status quo of CSS nesting

1050.title: Add ability to trigger autofill on form elements in webdriver-bidi specs

1057.title: Call stacks in crash reports from unresponsive web pages

1065.title: FedCM as a trust signal for the Storage Access API

1081.title: Declarative CSS Modules and Declarative Shadow DOM `adoptedstylesheets` attribute

1088.title: CSS Layout API
1088.description: An API for allowing web developers to define their own layout modes with javascript.
1088.rationale: This specification allows developing prototypes of new CSS layout systems and provides an escape hatch for developers when the existing systems aren't good enough for a particular piece of a web page.

1089.title: CSS Painting API
1089.description: An API for allowing web developers to define a custom CSS `<image>` with javascript, which will respond to style and size changes.
1089.rationale: This specification allows developing prototypes of new graphical CSS features and provides an escape hatch for developers when the existing features aren't good enough for a particular piece of a web page.

1090.title: CSS Properties and Values API
1090.description: This CSS module defines an API for registering new CSS properties. Properties registered using this API are provided with a parse syntax that defines a type, inheritance behaviour, and an initial value.
1090.rationale: This specification makes it significantly easier to use CSS custom properties in ways that are more like regular CSS properties.

1091.title: CSS Typed OM
1091.description: Converting CSSOM value strings into meaningfully typed JavaScript representations and back can incur a significant performance overhead. This specification exposes CSS values as typed JavaScript objects to facilitate their performant manipulation.
1091.rationale: This specification provides an easier way to manipulate the CSS object model.

1092.title: Custom elements
1092.description: A way to create new HTML elements implemented through JavaScript.

1093.title: HTML Imports
1093.description: HTML Imports are a way to include and reuse HTML documents in other HTML documents.
1093.rationale: Mozilla anticipated that JavaScript modules would change the landscape here and would rather invest in evolving that, e.g., through HTML Modules. Having a single mechanism to deal with dependencies rather than several, potentially conflicting systems, seems preferable.

1094.title: Shadow trees (formerly known as Shadow DOM)
1094.description: A way to give a node in the DOM a hidden subtree in which the children of the node can be inserted.

1097.title: Worklets
1097.description: This specification defines an API for running scripts in stages of the rendering pipeline independent of the main javascript execution environment.
1097.rationale: This specification is essential for allowing features like the CSS Paint API and CSS Layout API to be implemented in a safe way.

1098.title: template element
1098.description: The template element is used to declare fragments of HTML that can be cloned and inserted in the document by script.
1098.rationale: A reasonable addition to HTML (and XML), if not somewhat taxing on the parser.

1157.title: On-device Web Speech API
1157.description: This is a set of improvements to the Web Speech API specification that aims at adding features for users to perform speech-to-text and text-to-speech using the device's capabilities, without relying on web services. This also allows using Web Speech API with `MediaStreamTrack`.
1157.rationale: We believe this is a strong and welcome improvement to the API, on multiple aspects: added capabilities to the platform, in terms for feature and performance (e.g. being able to do high-quality low-latency recognition), but also accessibility and privacy.

1176.title: [Push API] Declarative Web Push
1176.description: Declarative Web Push introduces a JSON format that the user agent can recognize and parse without a Service Worker.
1176.rationale: We believe this proposal can reduce the required code size to subscribe push notifications, and it introduces a way for browsers to suppress potentially unwanted push notifications from tracking users.
